content:
Freddie Mercury’s final years with AIDS are airbrushed out of the film

“YOU’RE a legend, Fred,” says Roger Taylor (Ben Hardy), Queen’s drummer, shortly after Freddie Mercury (Rami Malek) has revealed to the band that he has AIDS. “We’re all legends,” the singer wistfully replies. The conversation sums up the problems with “Bohemian Rhapsody”, a new film about the band’s rise to fame.

First, it is typical of the movie’s hammy dialogue. It is hardly the sort of thing that friends say to each other when finding out that one of them has an incurable, devastating illness. Second, it is completely out of sync. In the film Mercury breaks the news to his bandmates while rehearsing for Live Aid in 1985, whereas in reality he was not diagnosed with the condition for another two years. And third, it hints at the difficulties of retelling a life that is already cherished by so many fans. The cheesy lines and tinkered timelines can be forgiven as the excesses of any Hollywood adaptation. But it is the grappling with the Mercury legend which kept the production in limbo for nearly a decade—and which ultimately weighs down a film with some strong individual performances.

That “Bohemian Rhapsody” has been released at all will delight Queen fans, who have been waiting since 2010. Screenwriters and directors have rushed in and out of the project. Bryan Singer, who was in the director’s chair when filming commenced, was fired with two weeks to go, after reportedly falling out with the cast. Mr Malek, an American actor of Egyptian descent who ended up playing Mercury, was the third person cast in the role, after Sacha Baron Cohen and Ben Whishaw had both dropped out. Mr Baron Cohen claimed that Mr Taylor and Brian May, the band’s guitarist (played by Gwilym Lee), were being too protective as producers. Not only did they envisage Mercury’s death as the midpoint in Queen’s story, he said, but they also wanted to leave out the more lurid details of his notoriously hedonistic life.

Both of those choices have been avoided. The bulk of the film shows the transformation of Farrokh Bulsara, an awkward, buck-toothed Parsi teenager, into Freddie Mercury, an outrageous showman who thrills his fans and skewers his critics. The part would be easy to overact, but Mr Malek inhabits it brilliantly, both when strutting on stage and when revealing his vulnerabilities. The screenwriters have hardly watered Mercury down. There are parties full of dwarfs and gimp masks, a coffee table covered in cocaine, and mockery for people that annoy him. “I pity your wife if you think six minutes is forever,” he quips at an executive who refuses to release “Bohemian Rhapsody” as a single. Another gets called a “treacherous piss flap”.

Those snipes are also directed at his bandmates. Messrs May and Taylor have not nostalgically glossed over the bickering among the quartet. The other three call Mercury “an arsehole” when he abandons them for a lucrative solo contract. John Deacon (Joseph Mazzello), the unassuming bassist who has some of the best zingers in the film, suggests that Mercury can use the extra cash to surround himself with people that will pretend to like him.

One of the film’s main flaws is that it focuses too much on this squabbling. Mercury’s brief solo defection barely features on Queen’s lengthy Wikipedia page, which notes that Mr May and Mr Taylor had released their own albums first. Yet it becomes the dramatic crux of the movie. The second act shows the singer alienating those who care about him, egged on by Paul Prenter, Mercury’s manager and first serious male lover. Prenter interferes with the recording process, encourages the singer to go solo and surrounds him with hangers-on. It is only after a visit from Mary Austin, Mercury’s one-time fiancée, that the singer realises the error of his ways. In the third act he ditches Prenter, who sells debauched tales to the media, and reunites his bandmates. They find out he has AIDS, play one of the all-time great gigs at Live Aid, then the credits roll to “Don’t Stop Me Now”.

It is uplifting stuff—and complete tosh. This truncated plot turns Queen’s story into a hackneyed tale of a band that suffers creative differences and yet still produces great music. What actually makes Queen’s history so compelling is the intensity of its final years with Mercury. The later songs reflected on his inevitable death even as he publicly denied that he had AIDS. “Who Wants to Live Forever” plays fleetingly near the film’s end when a doctor tells the singer that has tested positive for HIV. But when he breaks the news to the band, Mercury insists that he does not want to be a “poster boy” for the disease. The screenwriters use this as permission to ignore that period of his life altogether. There is no room on the soundtrack for “The Show Must Go On”, “Innuendo”, “Too Much Love Will Kill You”, “These Are the Days of Our Lives” or “Only the Good Die Young”, some of the most profound lyrics that the band ever wrote.

The result is a film that feels half-finished. Though Mr Baron Cohen feared that Mercury would die too early in the plot, in the end he does not die at all. That robs Mr Malek of the cHance to portray his subject’s most poignant years. It might prevent an excellent performance from being a prize-winning one, of the sort that earned Oscars for Tom Hanks in “Philadelphia” (1993) and Matthew McConaughey in “Dallas Buyers Club” (2013).

It also makes “Bohemian Rhapsody” a strange choice as the movie’s title. The song’s lyrics were eerily prescient of Mercury’s illness—“Too late, my time has come / Sends shivers down my spine / Body's aching all the time”—but the screenwriters have spared him his life of that monstrosity. A more apt name would have been “We Are the Champions”. This is really a movie about “fame and fortune and everything that goes with it”, which ends with the band on top.

Still, casual fans of the band’s hits will enjoy it. The actors are all dead ringers for their respective band members. Most of Mercury’s famous outfits appear. The reconstruction of Live Aid even includes a convincing Bob Geldof doppelgänger. But unfortunately this version of Queen is less the real life than a fantasy.

eg2: Fannie and Freddie account for half of all mortgages in the US.
房利美和房地美占据了美国抵押贷款的半壁江山。
Clearly, everything Fannie and Freddie did was because of the profit motive -- after all, they were private corporations.
很清楚，范尼梅和弗雷德马做的每一件事情都是因为追求利润---毕竟，他们都是私营企业。
Currently, most mortgages in the US flow through Fannie or , and nearly half of all outstanding mortgage debt is linked to them in some way.
现在，美国的大多数抵押贷款都流经房地美或房利美，在未偿付抵押贷款中，一半都与他们发生过某种关联。

eg2: After the trial, Mr. Hardy stayed indoors for a whole afternoon.
审讯之后，哈迪先生在室内待了整整一个下午。

因此，接下来的六个月，首席执行官罗杰•哈迪和其高管层每周都给客户打电话，看看他们有何想法。
I would have preferred the  Boys, preferred to gallop alongside the Riders of the Purple Sage, but I was afraid of teachers then, and so I read.
我本可以选择看《哈迪男孩》，我本可以选择看《紫艾灌丛中的骑士们》，但当时的我太怕老师，所以还是读了《杀死一只知更鸟》。

Where Brown had hints and , Cameron had an itemised list of policies and specifications.
卡梅隆在布朗有所暗示和影射的地方逐条列出了相关政策和标准。
After all, I had learned how to lead parallel lives as a child: most of the time, I could shut out all the accusations and  and go on with my work.
毕竟，我从小就学会了怎样把个人生活和公众生活分开：在大部分时间里，我都能够不理会各种各样的指责和影射，继续做我的工作。

eg2: Every bone in my body seems to .

Established truths are comforting, but it is the mysteries that make the soul  and render a life of exploration worth living.

一些男性把情绪闷在心里，以致于最后会一股脑儿爆发出来（这很不健康），或是疏远自己的伴侣或朋友。
If you can, turn that kind of sponsor away - it's not worth the money to  your audience.
要是你有能力，尽量拒绝这样的赞助商，不值得为了钱而疏远你的宾客们。

There are altogether 40 students in this class.
这个班总共有40名学生。
The analogy was well meant, but did not altogether please him.
这个比喻本是善意的，但却不能让他完全满意。

eg2: He is not doing this to annoy you.
他做这件事并非是要惹你烦恼。
We can annoy the enemy by air raids.
我们可以用空袭骚扰敌人。
I am convinced that some people complain just to annoy me, for something to do, or they simply enjoy complaining.
我以为身边的人抱怨是为了令我烦恼、是为了解决某些事、又或者他们就是喜欢抱怨。

朋友都会争论，会斗嘴，有时候甚至是打架，但这些都不会向对方关上彼此的大门。
They go hungry as North Korea and the United States bicker over how -- and in what language -- free food is to be handed over.
这些人因为朝美两国政府在如何-以及用何种语言来移交免费的粮食问题上争吵而遭受饥饿。

eg2: In the afternoon, they go back out, hoping for that .
下午，他们又回去了，渴望着那只雄鹿。
But it was a male, so they taught him to answer to“Frankie, ”short for Frank .
但是, 它是头公鹿。 他们教它熟悉“弗兰基”这个名字, 这是雄鹿弗兰克的简称。
Eventually those dollars will come home, they have to, as a function of math. In the meantime, passing the buck like a hot potato does not work.
从数学的功能上说，最终这些美元将必须回到美国。同时，将美元像个烫手山芋一样推出去是做不到的。

ex: n. 大部分；主体；（大）体积；大（量）
v. 扩展；增大；堆积起来；形成大块
网络 散装；大批；大量
eg2: The bulk of the population lives in cities.
大多数人口居住在城市里。
Despite its bulk and weight, the car is extremely fast.
尽管这辆车大而且重，速度却非常快。
a bulk order(= one for a large number of similar items)
一份大额订单
bulk buying(= buying in large amounts, often at a reduced price)
（常指以低价）大量购买
It's cheaper to buy in bulk .
大批购买便宜些。
She heaved her bulk out of the chair.
她挪动庞大的躯体，费力地从椅子里站起来。

ex: n. 临时工；便装；便鞋
adj. 不经意的；无忧无虑的；漫不经心的；不在乎的
网络 偶然的；随便的；临时的
eg2: a casual manner
漫不经心的样子
It was just a casual remark─I wasn't really serious.
我只是随便说说，并不当真。
He tried to sound casual, but I knew he was worried.
他讲话时试图显得不在乎，但我知道他心里着急。
They have a casual attitude towards safety(= they don't care enough) .
他们对安全问题采取无所谓的态度。
a casual glance
随便扫一眼
It's obvious even to the casual observer.
即便再马虎的人也能一眼看明白是怎么回事。
casual clothes(= comfortable clothes that you choose to wear in your free time)
便装
family parties and other casual occasions
家庭聚会和其他非正式场合
casual workers/labour
临时工
Students sometimes do casual work in the tourist trade.
学生有时做些旅游方面的零工。
They are employed on a casual basis(= they do not have a permanent job with the company) .
他们被雇为临时工。
a casual acquaintance
泛泛之交
a casual friendship
一般的友谊
to have casual sex(= to have sex without having a steady relationship with that partner)
做露水鸳鸯
a casual encounter/meeting
不期而遇；邂逅
a casual passer-by
碰巧过路的人
The exhibition is interesting to both the enthusiast and the casual visitor.
热心的爱好者和碰巧来参观的人都认为这个展览有意思。
The disease is not spread by casual contact.
此病不会通过偶然接触传染。
dressed in casuals
穿着便装

ex: adj. 干酪质的；下等的；虚伪的
eg2: “I felt her ass when she got over me to suds me up, ” he continued,  potatoes flecking from his mouth.
“她过来给我倒啤酒时我摸了她的屁股，”他继续说，奶酪马铃薯在他的嘴边留下斑点。
Instead they followed up the classic with a series of  sequels in the '80s that were totally unrelated to his book.
不过他们在80年代反倒是接着那部经典影片发行了一系列烂俗的续集，而且完全与他的那本书无关。
Vernix caseosa a white cheesy substance has formed over the baby’s skin to protect it from its watery environment and to help ease her through the birth canal.
胎儿皮脂——白色的干酪质的物质——已经在婴儿表面形成了，它可以保护婴儿免受水环境的影响并帮助婴儿舒适地通过产道。

ex: vt. 珍爱
vt. 怀有（感情等）；抱有（希望等）

wp.cherish time: 珍惜时间;珍惜时间英语作文
wp.Cherish Tonight: 今宵多珍重;难得是今晚

eg2: Life is hope, so we should cherish life.
生命就是希望,所以我们要珍爱生命.
My only other advice is to  every moment with those you love at every stage of your journey, as I have done this summer.
我唯一一个额外的建议就是在你人生旅途的每一段，珍爱与你所爱的每一个瞬间，正像我在今年夏天所做的那样。
What you need are things that you GENUINELY like. Things that you , that enhance your existence in the world.
但你真正需要的是你诚心喜欢的东西，你会珍爱它们同时它们也会提高你的社会地位。

ex: n. 可卡因；古柯碱
网络 古柯硷；柯卡因；可卡因类
v. 开始；着手；获得学位
eg2: The performances will  in a minute.
演出马上就开始。
This future is not fixed, but it is a destination that can be reached if we pursue a sustained dialogue like the one that you and we will commence today, and act on what we hear and what we learn.
未来并非一定如此，但是，如果我们坚持进行像今天即将开始的对话，并基于我们听到和学到的内容行事，这应当是一个能够达到的目标。
I shall forthwith commence the duties of the high trust to which you have called me.
